_accidents.CF_Other: Failure of valve manufacturer to adhere to design standards

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Coffeyville Resources Nitrogen Fertilizers, LLC
Risk Management Plan

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY 

1 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The Coffeyville Resources Nitrogen Fertilizer (CRNF) Plant has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety and protecting the environment. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, including training of personnel and safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of the processes at the CRNF Plant.  CRNF implements reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. CRNF places emphasis on prevention, prompt detection, and expeditious correction of unsafe conditions by periodically conducting internal inspection and regularly training responsible personnel. Should a release occur, the plant's trained personnel will respond to control, contain, and mitigate the release.

2 STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

CRNF operates a variety of processes to produce anhydrous ammonia and urea-ammonium nitrate (UAN) solutions. The CRNF Plant has several processes that contain more than a threshold quantity of a regulated substance, anhydrous ammonia, and a flammable mixture consisting of hydrogen, carbon monoxide, hydrogen sulfide and methane.  The CRNF Plant includes a total of six (6) RMP covered processes. The CRNF Plant is subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation.

3 WORST CASE SCENARIO EVALUATION
 
CRNF has evaluated worst case scenarios for both the release of a regulated substance and also for a flammable mixture.  Potential alternate cases for a regulated substance and flammable mixture were also evaluated.  Based on the results of these evaluations, CRNF has put in place response training and procedures to prevent or mitigate the potential for off-site consequences.

4A GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM 

The CRNF Plant h

as implemented an accidental release prevention program. The accidental release prevention program required for Program 3 processes is summarized as follows:

Process Safety Information
Complete and accurate written process safety information concerning process chemicals, process technology, and process equipment is essential to an effective accident prevention program, as well as completing and maintaining a process hazard analysis. The process safety information is readily available to all employees and used by plant personnel, the process hazard analysis team, and persons in charge of updating the emergency response plan. CRNF maintains a variety of technical documents that are used to maintain safe operations. These documents address toxicity information, chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters, specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis and configuration. Chemical specific information, including physical data, reactivity data, corrosivity data, thermal and chemical stability data, permissible exposure limits, hazards of inadvertent mixing of materials, and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations are provided in Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS).

CRNF also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment at the plant. This information includes, but is not limited to, materials of construction, design pressure ratings, temperature ratings, and electrical rating of equipment. This information in combination with written procedures and trained personnel provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and plant changes to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised.

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)
The plant has a comprehensive program to ensure that hazards associated with the processes are identified and controlled. Within this program,

each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.  

CRNF primarily uses the hazard and operability analysis (HAZOP) and What-if/Checklist methodologies to perform these evaluations. The analyses are conducted using a team of plant personnel who have operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise and may include third parties knowledgeable in the process hazard analysis methodology being used. This team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures. The team makes suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are needed. Any identified risks are promptly addressed. Resolution of each finding is documented and records of the analyses are retained.

To ensure that the process controls and/or process hazards do not significantly deviate from the original design safety features, the plant periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results. These periodic reviews are conducted at least every five years unless review is warranted sooner due to a significant change at the plant. Once again, the reviews are documented and records of the review are retained.

Operating Procedures
CRNF maintains written procedures at the plant that address each operating phase of process operations such as: (1) initial start-up; (2) normal operations; (3) temporary operations; (4) emergency shutdown; (5) emergency operations; (6) normal shutdown; and (7) startup following a turnaround, or after an emergency shutdown. These procedures also address operating limits, safety and health considerations and safety systems and their functions.

Operating procedures are reviewed periodically and as operational changes are introduced, and annually certified as current and accurate. Both operators and technical staff participate in the review and certification proces

s.  Operating procedures provide current, clearly written instructions for operating the processes. Instructions include applicable safety precautions and appropriate information on safety implications. Operating procedures ensure that all employees operate the processes in a prescribed, consistent, and safe manner.

Training
CRNF has a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating the processes at the plant. New employees receive training in an overview of the process and procedures and other safe work practices applicable to the employee's job tasks.  In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level. This refresher training is conducted as frequently as needed but no less often than every three years. All training is documented for each operator including the means to verify that the operator understood the training.

Mechanical Integrity
CRNF has practices and procedures for maintaining process vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps at the plant. The aspects of this program include: (1) training; (2) written procedures; (3) inspection frequency and testing procedures; (4) correcting identified equipment deficiencies; and (5) applying quality assurance measures. These activities form a system to maintain the mechanical integrity of the processes.

CRNF incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs. This helps to ensure that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made.

Management of Change
CRNF has comprehensive system to manage change to the processes at the plant. Changes to process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process operating conditions), procedures, changes to the quantity of regulated substances in the process, and other

process changes are properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented. Reviews ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and to verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change. Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures, are updated to incorporate a change. In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are notified of changes and, if necessary, trained on the changes.

Pre-Startup Review 
CRNF conducts a pre-startup safety review (PSSR) on any new process or process modification that is significant enough to require a change in process safety information. The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to introducing regulated substances into the process. This review provides an additional check that construction is in accordance with design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready. The PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves as a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented.

Compliance Audits
CRNF periodically conducts and certifies that they have performed audits to determine the implementation of the procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program. Compliance audits are conducted at least every three years.

An audit team develops findings that are forwarded to plant management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until resolution. The resolution of each finding is documented. The two most recent audit reports are retained.

Incident Investigation
CRNF promptly investigates all incidents that result in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  In addition CRNF investigates any f

ire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury. The goal of each investigation is to gather the facts, determine the root cause, and develop corrective action for the prevention of the same or a similar incident. Findings and recommendations are documented and are forwarded to plant management for resolution and records of such are maintained for five years.

Employee Participation
Active employee participation and involvement in the development and implementation of the plant's accident prevention program is a critical component of the overall objective to prevent or minimize the consequences of a catastrophic release of a flammable or toxic substance. Employee involvement helps to ensure that all perspectives regarding accident prevention are considered for implementation. Open communications are encouraged between supervisors and employees regarding all aspects of safety and health issues concerning employees, contractors and the public.

CRNF strongly promotes employee involvement in safety issues through, for example, regularly scheduled safety meetings, tail gate safety meetings, hazard communications, safety suggestions, incident reporting system, and special training programs such as emergency response training and first aid training.  CRNF actively seeks employee involvement in the development and implementation of all accident prevention activities through the appropriate programs.  Accident prevention is discussed at the regularly scheduled safety meetings and/or during special training sessions, if necessary.  Employees are encouraged to discuss accident prevention with their supervisors and to bring any questions, comments or suggestions forward for open discussion.

Hot work permit
CRNF has a procedure and a hot work permit system in place that documents the fire prevention and protection requirements of 29 CFR 1910.252(a).  The facility also has other safe work practices in place to help ensure

worker and safety. Examples of these include: (1) control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel; (2) a lockout/tagout procedure to ensure isolation of energy sources for eqequipment undergoing maintenance; (3) a procedure for safe removal of hazardous substances before process piping and equipment is opened and; (4) a permit and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space. These procedures, along with training of affected personnel, form a system to ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely at the plant.

Contractors
CRNF uses contractors to supplement its workforce and during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities. Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, the plant has procedures in place to ensure that contractors: (1) perform their work in a safe manner; (2) have appropriate knowledge and skills; (3) are aware of the hazards of their workplace; (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency; (5) understand and follow site-specific safety rules; and (6) inform plant personnel of any hazards that they find while performing their work. This is accomplished by providing contractors with an orientation session that covers: (1) a process overview; (2) information about the safety and health hazards; (3) emergency response plan requirements; and (4) safe work practices prior to beginning their work. In addition, CRNF evaluates contractor safety programs and performance during the contractor selection process. CRNF personnel periodically monitor contractor performance to ensure that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations.

4B CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
Hazards in the processes are continually managed to ensure safe operations. The existing safety features to prevent accidental releases of regulated substances in the plant are described below.

For the regulated substance ammonia, CRNF has reviewed a

nd adopted industry guidelines and recommendations regarding safe storage and handling. This includes personnel training as well as robust equipment designs. For the flammable mixture, CRNF has adopted several API, NFPA, insurance company, ASME, ANSI, and other codes and standards.

Uniform Prevention Activities
The accident prevention program is applied throughout the RMP-covered processes. These prevention programs are designed and implemented to prevent potential accidental release scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and/or human errors.

Specialized Safety Features
Safety features are incorporated into the design, construction, operation and maintenance of the processes to help prevent, quickly detect and control a release, and to reduce the consequences of a release. The following types of safety features are used in the covered processes:

Release Detection
- Ammonia detectors and alarms
- Detectors and alarms for other chemicals in the process
Release Containment and Control
- Process relief valves that discharge to flares to capture and/or incinerate episodic releases
- Remote Isolation Valves for safe isolation of the process (manual or automated)
Automatic shutdown systems for specific process
Curbs or dikes to contain liquid releases
Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system)
Total plant emergency shutdown (ESD) Plan
Release Mitigation
- Fire suppression and extinguishing systems
- Deluge system for specific equipment
- Trained on-site emergency response organization
- Hand-held and wheeled cart fire extinguishers
- Personal protective equipment (e.g., chemical protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus, etc.).


5 FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The facility investigated two accidental releases during the past five years that met the RMP rule definition and/or had a potential RMP off-site impact. The first accidental release occurred on 11/1

/2008 and resulted in a public road being closed for a short period of time but did not result in any injuries or property damage.

The second accidental release occurred on 9/30/2010 and resulted in on-site property damage, off-site property damage, and medical treatment to off-site personnel. An incident investigation was conducted and actions taken on identified correctable opportunities.

6 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The CRNF Plant maintains a written Emergency Response Plan to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. The program consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first-aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post incident management. In addition, the facility has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment. Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties. The emergency response program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to the plant processes.  CRNF's program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations. 

CRNF coordinates its emergency response program and response actions with the Montgomery County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  This coordination includes periodic meetings that include local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives. The CRNF Plant has around-the-clock communications capability with emergen
